Let's tackle the trickiest part:

How to center horizontally and vertically using one line of CSS?

It's simple using only one line of code

place-content: center;

{ 26 / 28  } https://t.co/a3GpTg6qAd

We can use justify-self and align-self in order to set the alignment of a particular item with the grid container

{ 25 / 28  } https://t.co/ZSEAPwf5kI

The `align-items` property specifies the default alignment for items inside the flexible container.

ğŸ”— https://t.co/b4kUoUWHFV

{ 24 / 28  } https://t.co/a078hLosiA

The `justify-content` is used to align the container's items when the items do not use all available space on the main-axis (horizontally).

ğŸ”— https://t.co/5L3VY6e5UI

{ 23 / 28  } https://t.co/0Awn3bDBDc

ğŸ“Œ Alignment in CSS Grid Layout

This is a little confusing thing but we will cover everything in this thread.

justify-content
align-items
justify-self
align-self

{ 22 / 28  }

Here is the visual example, by default the correct order should be 1 2 3 4 but I have applied order property to change the actual ordering.

{ 21 / 28  } https://t.co/lwyDrzWRiT

Let's breakdown this code

  grid-template-areas: 'areaName areaName areaName areaName areaName';

- Each row is defined by apostrophes (' ')
- Hence only one row in this case as there is only one pair of apostrophes
- Five "areaName" hence five columns

CONT...

{ 17 / 28  } https://t.co/cX1clUVrZx

Alright moving forward, The next property we have is `grid-template-areas` which specifies the areas within the grid layout.

Each row is defined by apostrophes (' ')

Sounds confusing? Let see this in action

{ 16 / 28  }

We can change the position of a particular item in accordance of row and column 

For example, I want my first item to take up entire row, that is from the first column to the last column 

grid-column: 1 / 4;

{ 15 / 28  } https://t.co/JHT2VOGlv4

Well, all that we have covered so far we can do that using flexbox also.

Let's understand the 2 dimensions of grid layout

{ 14 / 28  } https://t.co/13dV2PNsgi

In order to prevent this kind of issues we have minmax function 

grid-auto-rows: minmax(200px, auto);

It's pretty intuitive that the height of gird items will be 200px minimum and "auto" maximum(according to content)

{ 13 / 28  } https://t.co/K0Mmr5d6gs

Though there is a problem. By doing this, we are setting the fixed height so content inside items can be overflow.

For example:

{ 12 / 28  } https://t.co/TqbPwNXUIj

You can use repeat function for fr as well

repeat(2, 1fr 2fr);

It will repeat 1fr 2fr two times.

{ 10 / 28  } https://t.co/ZXihfhNrzd

You might run into some responsiveness issues if you pass pixel unit or percentage in your grid-template-columns

In order to prevent this, it is recommended to use fraction values

For example:

{ 09 / 28  } https://t.co/LFXbJpXZIX

Similarly we have grid-template-rows.

It is used to define the number of rows and height of rows.

grid-template-rows: 200px 400px;

{ 07 / 28  } https://t.co/p9YTlwl8ow

Ahh!! My grid items look ugly as there is no spacing between them. 
Here "grid-gap" property comes into play. For example, I need 10px spacing along column and row

grid-gap: 10px;

{ 06 / 28  } https://t.co/P1rqYMMBWQ

Let's start with defining the width of our columns.

For example, let's say I need two columns of width 60% and 40% respectively

grid-template-columns: 60% 40%;

{ 05 / 28  } https://t.co/6h6SdvEKu4

Nothing will change after adding display: flex; in the parent container because we need to define the width of columns. In order to set that column's width we have gird-template-columns property.

{ 04 / 28  }

First things first, start with giving the display property "grid" to the container element or parent element.

{ 03 / 28  } https://t.co/Cx2Guc9GFm

Grid is used for making complex web design layouts more easily as it's not so hard to master

Using Flex you can make only 1D layout but Grid gives you the full power of creating a 2D layout

Let's start

And that's it. You just created your first react app. I tried my best to give a quick overview of how things work in React

If you like this thread, drop a like and retweet, means a lot to me â¤ï¸

Peace out ğŸ˜‰

Once done, run "npm start"

Your default browser will launch automatically and you will see something like this at localhost:3000 https://t.co/8Fg7cCzkoJ

Now you have create-react-app installed in your machine, it's time to create your first React app

Command - "create-react-app app-name"

Depending upon your internet speed, this will take some minutes. So time to prepare a coffee for yourself â˜•
Next thing you need to install is `create-react-app` is a tool helps you start building with React app. It set up all the tools that you need in order to get started

Setting up your first react project directory is quite confusing. Let's see how you can do it

I'm assuming you have node environment set up and up-to-date version of npm. If no, download it from here

 https://t.co/5Om0LeuKxr

Whenever the new element is added to the UI, a new virtual DOM associated with that element is created. If state of this element changes, a second new virtual DOM is created which will be compared with the previous virtual DOM

- It then updates ONLY the object on the real DOM https://t.co/XcRHmtT4A5

Every time the DOM changes, browser need to recalculate entire layout and then repaint the web page which makes a web app slow. 

To overcome this we have virtual DOM
Every time the state of our application changes, the virtual DOM gets updated instead of the real DOM

A very important concept in React

Virtual DOM

You might have heard the term "DOM", virtual DOM is kind of similar. It uses a strategy that updates the DOM without having to redraw all the webpage elements

Now we know JSX, let's move forward

- Functional components are nothing but simply a JavaScript function which takes some parameter will return some JSX code

A typical function component ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» https://t.co/vCGnZH7qiA

const element = <h1>Hello, world!</h1>;

Consider this variable declaration. It's neither JS nor HTML. This is the mixture of JavaScript + XML = JSX

Before diving deeper into it, let's talk a little bit about JSX

- JSX stands for JavaScript XML. It's basically nothing but the extension of JavaScript which allow us to write HTML code in JavaScript file.

Components are of two types:

1ï¸âƒ£ Class based components 
2ï¸âƒ£ functional based components 

Class-based components are defined using ES6 classes, whereas function components are basic JavaScript functions

Attached image showing a typical React app with all different components. 
As you can see this entire webpage is nothing but the mixture of different components https://t.co/pgknsZ0Mh4

A typical React app contain many components. They are reusable and can interact with each other.

What is a component?
- Component as a simple function that you can call with some input and they render some output

Why React?

1. Reusable components
2. Fast due to virtual DOM
3. Huge ecosystem

Introduction to React âš›ï¸

React is a JavaScript library for building UI components. The ecosystem of React is really immense which eventually makes it one of the best front-end libraries.

ğŸ“Œ Changing HTML Element

- element.innerHTML
- element.attribute
- element .style.property
- element.setAttribute(attr, value)

Pushpin Adding and deleting elements

- document.createElement(element)

Basic things you need to cover in DOM

ğŸ“Œ Finding HTML Elements

- getElementsByTagName()
- getElementsById()
- getElementsByClassName()
Don't get confused here. DOM is not a programming language it's just a model using which we can access and modify HTML elements,

JavaScript and DOM are connected.

We use DOM to access the elements but write JavaScript code in order to modify them.

Here is a simple example: https://t.co/SZ3ocBjiJ3

DOM gives you a superpower to change your webpage at your convenience using JavaScript.

- You change the HTML elements, attribute, styles
- You can delete existing HTML elements
- You can add HTML elements

Let's talk about DOM a little bit. It stands for Document Object Model.

Consider it as a tree that comprises the content of a particular web page (HTML) https://t.co/qtHs0y0rFs

You need to cover some intermediate topics so that you can add behaviour to your website. They are

- Arrays and their methods
- Objects
- Functions
- Arrow function

These will help you to work with DOM. https://t.co/pRPydMX8qg

There are some advanced topics in JavaScript which you don't need to learn in the beginning. For ex:

- Async/await
- callbacks, promises, etc...

These are some advance concept which you can learn after

When I started learning web development, I had basic knowledge about Java language which helped me a lot because I was no more in a need to learn about these general programming concepts.

But you can start with the ZERO knowledge as well.

First and foremost, it's a programming language so you should know about basic programming concepts:

- Data types in JavaScript
- Variables
- Statements
- Control statements
- Operators
- And other basic stuff....

JavaScript is a kind of language that as you progress deeper in the field, you will come to know a lot more cool concepts about it.

In order to display the pseudo-elements below the parent element, you just need to remove the z-index from the parent itself. For example: https://t.co/mzvh5UJkYq
For example, this won't work ğŸ‘‡ https://t.co/rVPTphPzQc

ğŸ”¹ z-index of pseudo-elements

By default pseudo-elements(::before and ::after) display on the top of the parent.

You can set the stacking order of ::before and ::after as usual but you can't display pseudo-elements below the parent...

ğŸ”¹ z-index of nested elements

Let's say two elements A and B are siblings with element B written after element A in DOM, then the children of element A cannot be higher than element B no matter what z-index is being applied on children

See this in action â¬ https://t.co/octmVad4Tm

Note that z-index only works on positioned elements.

You need to specify the position (relative, absolute, sticky, fixed) if you want to arrange an element using z-index https://t.co/31RLP9TSAs

z-index is a CSS property that controls the stacking order of elements along the z-axis. 

Image a hypothetical line starting from your eye to screen, that is z-axis

Have you found the "z-index" a confusing concept of CSS?

ğŸ“Œ Responsive Web Design (RWD)

An extremely important topic in CSS. Responsive web design is little tricky but not so tough to master.

It covers

- media query
- layouts

In this thread, you'll find everything about CSS grid and web layout

https://t.co/d4KDenrGd8

ğŸ“Œ Layout

- CSS positioning
- Flexible box layout
- Grid layout

Structuring your website is essential as it provides better navigation and visualization of the content available on the site. Let's talk a little more about it and learn how we can create a proper layout.

ğŸ“Œ Typography

Moving forward, typography is an essential thing of web page. A good font can make your webpage and establish a strong visual hierarchy, provide a graphic balance to the website, and set the product's overall tone

ğŸ“Œ The box-model

The entire website is a combination of boxes

The box-model covers

- Height
- Width
- Padding
- Border
- Margin

Here is the detailed thread on the box model: https://t.co/2iPn0jfJO2

The background in the shorthand property which covers background-color, background-attachment, etc

But again, you will rarely use background-attachment, background-origin, etc

First and foremost

ğŸ“Œ The background and color

The characterstic of a great website is it's color scheme. Forget about everything and learn about background and color properties initially
The colors are something from which users interact first whenever they visit your webpage
Lets talk about some important concepts which you should know to be a fron-end developer ğŸ‘‡ğŸ»

There are a lot of these types of properties in CSS which you never gonna use for sure.

Like,

ğŸ“Œ caret-color
ğŸ“Œ mask-composite
ğŸ“Œ will-change

For example: Have you heard about "image-rendering property"?

If not, then its not a problem
if yes, then its great

This property basically defines the image scalinig algorithm https://t.co/mpho57eNw2

You must have heard about "Pareto principle" which states that for many outcomes roughly 80% of consequences come from 20% of the causes

Similarly, in order to cover 80% of CSS, you need to learn only 20 properties https://t.co/r0yGTwyNY0

Obviously remembering them all and their values is almost impossible.

In my opinion, entire CSS revolves around 20 properties only
CSS is totally operates on properties value pair. And there are around ~300 distinct properties in CSS

Whenever the new element is added to the UI, a new virtual DOM associated with that element is created. If state of this element changes, a second new virtual DOM is created which will be compared with the previous virtual DOM

- It then updates ONLY the object on the real DOM https://t.co/m47FHXfej9

Every time the DOM changes, the browser needs to recalculate the entire layout and then repaint the web page which makes a web app slow

To overcome this we have virtual DOM
Every time the state of our application changes, the virtual DOM gets updated instead of the real DOM

Virtual DOM

You might have heard the term "DOM", virtual DOM is kind of similar. It uses a strategy that updates the DOM without having to redraw all the webpage elements.

Let's tackle the trickiest part:

How to center horizontally and vertically using one line of CSS?

It's simple using only one line of code

place-content: center;

Let's breakdown this code

  grid-template-areas: 'areaName areaName areaName areaName areaName';

- Each row is defined by apostrophes (' ')
- Hence only one row in this case as there is only one pair of apostrophes
- Five "areaName" hence five columns

CONT...

{ 17 / 28  } https://t.co/UC5WkByx0k

Alright moving forward, The next property we have is `grid-template-areas` which specifies the areas within the grid layout.

Each row is defined by apostrophes (' ')

Sounds confusing? Let see this in action

{ 16 / 28  }

We can change the position of a particular item in accordance of row and column 

For example, I want my first item to take up entire row, that is from the first column to the last column 

grid-column: 1 / 4;

Well, all that we have covered so far we can do that using flexbox also.

Let's understand the 2 dimensions of grid layout

In order to prevent this kind of issues we have minmax function 

grid-auto-rows: minmax(200px, auto);

It's pretty intuitive that the height of gird items will be 200px minimum and "auto" maximum(according to content)

repeat(2, 1fr 2fr);

The most important concept on which the entire JavaScript language based on

The Event Loop

https://t.co/U7t4uCI1JP

Here is the complete general introduction to JavaScript

https://t.co/USDFAs7ms7

Up to this point you will able to make a fully functional website using JavaScript. But there are always some margin of improvement

Here are some advanced key concepts

- Hoisting
- Closures
- Callbacks
- Promises
- Async & Await
- Currying
- And other ES6 feature

Just one last thing and then you will be able to make fully-fledged websites.

After learning these basic properties and methods, its time to move onto Events and Event Listener

The addEventListener() method attaches an event handler to the specified element.

ğŸ“Œ Changing HTML Element

- element.innerHTML
- element.attribute
- element .style.property
- element.setAttribute(attr, value)

Pushpin Adding and deleting elements

- document.createElement(element)
- document.removeChild(element)
- document.appendChild(element)

Basic things you need to cover in DOM

ğŸ“Œ Finding HTML Elements

- getElementsByTagName()
- getElementsById()
- getElementsByClassName()
Don't get confused here. DOM is not a programming language it's just a model using which we can access and modify HTML elements,

JavaScript and DOM are connected.

We use DOM to access the elements but write JavaScript code in order to modify them.

Here is a simple example: https://t.co/Q5WMBrX4qs

DOM gives you a superpower to change your webpage at your convenience using JavaScript.

- You change the HTML elements, attribute, styles
- You can delete existing HTML elements
- You can add HTML elements

Let's talk about DOM a little bit. It stands for Document Object Model.

Consider it as a tree that comprises the content of a particular web page (HTML) https://t.co/C82NbFPhi4

You need to cover some intermediate topics so that you can add behaviour to your website. They are

- Arrays and their methods
- Objects
- Functions
- Arrow function

These will help you to work with DOM. https://t.co/s8aGxr72nC

There are some advanced topics in JavaScript which you don't need to learn in the beginning. For ex:

- Async/await
- callbacks, promises, etc...

These are some advance concept which you can learn after

When I started learning web development, I had basic knowledge about Java language which helped me a lot because I was no more in a need to learn about these general programming concepts.

But you can start with the ZERO knowledge as well.

First and foremost, it's a programming language so you should know about basic programming concepts:

- Data types in JavaScript
- Variables
- Statements
- Control statements
- Operators
- And other basic stuff....

JavaScript is a kind of language that as you progress deeper in the field, you will come to know a lot more cool concepts about it.

Prerequisites if you want to learn JavaScript for web development ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» 

- HTML
- CSS

JavaScript is an enormous language but you don't need to learn everything in the beginning.

ğŸ“Œ 10. Try to win the trust of your audience

Social media is all about building trust online. Contribute in the community as much as you can so that people start loving you

ğŸ“Œ 9. Put your true values

Nothing can be achieved without the efforts. Try to help others as much as you can.

I help others by writing long threads and creating handmade cheatsheets ğŸ’–

ğŸ“Œ 8. Consider yourself as a part of your audience

This is the key point for me and it helps me to come up with new and interesting ideas for my content.

I try to cover some difficult and tricky concepts in which I faced some difficulties when I was first learning it
Some of my "I agree" replies... https://t.co/S4aCizcrtN

ğŸ“Œ 7. Reply reply and reply

Social media is nothing without interaction.

Thank you!
I agree!
Awesome stuff!

This is not interaction. If you agree with someone's tweet don't just write I agree, give a proper reason why you agree. For example ğŸ‘‡ğŸ»
Write something in your bio which can be motivational to others. Check out Oliver's (@oliverjumpertz) bio. He has 20+ years of experience which is close to my age ğŸ˜… https://t.co/xNu53xulDE
I have seen many accounts using hashtags in their bio. Immediately remove them, they are just making your profile look spammy. Just an opinion

ğŸ“Œ 5. Hashtags

I'm not sure whether hashtags actually increase the reach of your tweets, but to the human eye, hashtags make your tweets unpromising.

I used to use hashtags but only 2 or at most 3 and once I crossed 500 followers I never used hashtags again

ğŸ“Œ 4. Don't be a content bot

Posting something related to your life, work or any other details would also prevent you from being a content bot

- Hence don't just put content or resources, talk a little bit about other stuff as well

Some big and fully-fledged thread needs a little bit of planning so that we can deliver stuff accurately and in proper sequence. 

For example: While writing this thread, I have already written some key points

ğŸ“Œ 3. Do you actually need planning before posting?

Social media is not all about sharing resources and content only. You can also share some random stuff related to your day-to-day life. And I guess there is no planning required for this type of tweets

For example: ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» https://t.co/O682QkGWCw

ğŸ“Œ 2. Frequency of your tweet

I analyzed many profiles and one glimpse I found is the inconsistency in the initial phase. Everything takes time. Try to post at least one tweet per.

Once people will start recognizing you by your content then you can push the boundaries of your content.

I started with CSS arts but now I post about

- Web development
- React
- audience building tips
- Motivational
- and some other stuff ğŸ˜

Why?

Obviously, you can put diverse content as well but we need to tell the community that, hey, I am X and I am good at Y technology.

This will bring quick light to your profile.

ğŸ“Œ 1. Make your place in the well-established tech community

This sounds tough but actually, it is not. You just need to put content but try to deliver the content from the one technology.

For example, When I started, I posted only CSS arts nothing else

I randomly started Twitter but built ~100K audience in about 12 months

10. sepia()

The sepia() CSS function converts the input image to sepia, giving it a warmer, more yellow/brown appearance. https://t.co/woG6XDB30u

9. saturate()

The CSS saturate function helps to reduce or increase the saturation level of the input image. https://t.co/mbeRIJNYSD

8. opacity()

Opacity function applies transparency to the samples in the input image https://t.co/L398OJRmYy

7. invert()

invert function simply invert the color of the element https://t.co/sU6p453Cyp

5. grayscale()

The grayscale() CSS function converts the input image to grayscale https://t.co/TmwW0wNcwO

4. drop-shadow()

box-shadow applies the shadow around rectangular box whereas drop-shadow automatically fits around the shape of an element https://t.co/i6GDx3CpW9

3. contrast()

You can adjust the contrast of the input image. Contrast is like the difference in brightness between objects or regions https://t.co/dwlkfZBvwJ

2. brightness

Brightness function adds some visual perception in the input image, making it appear brighter or darker https://t.co/H3NOkhmfk4

1. blur

As the term suggests, blur function simply blurs your input image. The blur that is being applied to image is known and Gaussian blur https://t.co/MBqfymhjX0

CSS filter functions provide us the flexibility of adding graphical effects to an element. They are

- blur()
- brightness()
- contrast()
- drop-shadow()
- hue-rotate()
- grayscale()
- invert()
- opacity()
- sepia()
- saturate()

I have a video tutorial on YouTube explaining about useReducer in more bit details. 

Check it out: https://t.co/nt4hZzInIR

This may sound a little confusing for the first time. Don't worry I created a notes app for you using the useReducer hook.

Check out the code and try to play around with it for better understanding.

https://t.co/TCPEn0W3Pz

What if I want to pass some values through dispatch to the reducer function?

Here is "payload" comes into play. It is used to pass the value which represents the payloads of the action.

For example, suppose I want to pass "temp" variable ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» 

https://t.co/6BlaBeul1U https://t.co/oxYLBP01td
Generally, we can pass different actions through dispatch to reducer via an object. https://t.co/4e5HaaQAIC
The reducer function accepts the second argument as well known as "action" using which we can tell the reducer function that what operations need to perform on the state.

Now we can simply update our state by passing the state parameter in the reducer function.

Something like this ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» https://t.co/zelwCBfbx8

So far we haven't seen how the state can be managed using this.

Before that one thing to note here is that useReducer is for handling more complex states hence it is recommended to passing the current state as an object https://t.co/BkSd6FaIU1

Let's try to see this into action. 

I just implemented a basic code here. Basically, I am calling dispatch function on button click which will eventually call reducer function https://t.co/iB5VtvJBtT

Now we know that useReducer takes three parameters and return two values

Here is the complete syntax ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» https://t.co/rSaEiKCW5i

The useReducer hook accepts 3 parameter

1. reducer
2. Initial state
3. init

The first value is `undefined` which is the current state (it is undefined because we didn't pass any initial state in the useReducer hook)

The second value is a dispatch function using which we can update our state.
Similar to useState, the useReducer hook also returns a pair of values. Let's see what these two things are https://t.co/HSI8GkeFRQ

Usually, the useState hook is used to tackle states in React where you can pass the initial state and React preserves state for you between re-renders

What if you need to manage more complex states? Here useReducers comes into play

React Hooks are so powerful and especially some additional hooks.

Do you know there is an alternative to useState called useReducer hook? It is used to manage more complex states.

In this thread, I have compiled some general tips to make your website responsive 

https://t.co/P2f4yNA5zm

1. Use meta viewport element
2. Don't use a large fixed width
3. Try to use Layouts
4. Use box-sizing: border-box
5. Media Queries are saviour
6. Use "auto" in media
7. Use frameworks if possible

Responsive web design is little tricky but not so tough to master. There are few quick points you need to remember while writing CSS code

I would suggest you to take care of responsiveness while writing CSS rather than handling responsiveness in the end.

Hmm, awesome!! I think you're all set to learn about responsiveness here. 

Don't skip it. There are millions of devices on which your website is viewed.

Layouts can save your time as well. It's an important concept to learn because it plays an important role in responsive web design(RWD)

https://t.co/XtbgA0eWBf

Up to this point, you have some decent knowledge of styling your website. It would be great if you learn about a layout system now.

There are five basic classifications of fonts: 

1. serif 
2. sans serif 
3. script 
4. monospaced
5. display

Give this article a read for more detailed explanation

https://t.co/077FP0f0zz

Moving forward, typography is an essential thing of web page. A good font can make your webpage and establish a strong visual hierarchy, provide a graphic balance to the website, and set the product's overall tone.

You can add free fonts from Google's official site

Border are used to set the color, width and style to elements. You can learn it in 5 min

Some good border selection can give your element a good pleasant look

Proper and uniform separation of elements is something that can give your webpage an appealing look. Margin and padding can do this for you. 

Give this article a short read for a Definitive guide of padding and margin
https://t.co/eEEHcxwchQ

Height and width properties are pretty intuitive. These are used to set fixed height and width to the element
 
I suggest giving a look at max, min-width, and max, min-height properties as well.
Don't think that background property is just for setting the solid color. Background is a shorthand property for background-image, background-position etc..

There are a lot of great color palette out there using which you can generate pleasant color schemes

Check this great tool for generating accessible colors

https://t.co/ndsgBauTEc https://t.co/EPHqTEFIBF

ğŸ“Œ Let's talk about how complex these two modules are

The syntax of transition is a little easier than animation hence it is recommended to use CSS transition while manipulating DOM
The other thing to note here is that we can't change multiple properties while working with CSS transition but CSS animation provides us this functionality.
On the other hand, the animation is defined by a keyframe at-rule which varies from one state to another with various properties and time frames. https://t.co/hds5Oq82pq

Watch the above video again, We can say that transition is a two-point operation that takes place between point A and point B

In the above example, 

Point A - Initial point - 100px height
Point B - Final point - 200px height

Consider this, When I hover over the box, the height changes.

Here hover is the trigger https://t.co/YXvaIWhIhr

Transition is something that needs to be triggered. For example, changing the height when the user hover the element

On the other side, animations do not need to be triggered.
Though there are some similarities in animation and transition but first let's try to find out the real difference

CSS Animation and CSS Transition are two different modules of CSS but many of us get confused that when to use which one?

Let's try to explore more about them ğŸ§µ ğŸ‘‡ğŸ»

Peace out ğŸ˜‰
Hence these three components, The call stack, the event queue and the web APIs makes a cycle which is known as event loop. https://t.co/xCAa4IwZcN

So, setTimeout function was sent to web API, which waited there for specific time period and after that it was sent to queue for processing

That's why the output of above code is 

one
three
two

ğŸ“Œ Web API 

This is where the browser API or web API comes into play. These API are pre built into the browsers.

Whenver an async function comes is call stack, it is sent to web API which waits for the specified time to send this operation back to event queue https://t.co/n4RVrdnnij

The output in this particular case is

one
three
two

Why did this happen?

As you can see, one, two and three is being printed out as they appeared in the code in serial order.

But now consider this piece of code ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» https://t.co/kFGdlyjsVy
So far everything is normal. Lets try to visualize it. Consider the following code and output ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» https://t.co/HJ5oJOmiep

Event Queue

It is responsible for sending new functions to the call stack for processing. It follows the queue data structure to maintain the correct sequence in which all operations should be sent for execution. https://t.co/I5dGEufOKL

Call stack

It keeps all the operations in order which has to be executed. After successful execution of a operation, it is popped out. https://t.co/1jZq26k08N

ğŸ“Œ Lets break the Event loop and see what we find inside

Event loop is made up of two data structures

1. Stack
2. Queue

ğŸ“Œ What exactly event loop is?

Event loop is a programming concept or design pattern that makes the JavaScript a multithreaded language

Before diving into it, we need to understand what multithreading is?

Multithreading is nothing but a programming feature by which we can make maximum use of CPU by running two or more parts of program simultaneously

Introduction to Event Loop â°

Event loop is the confusing concept in JavaScript but you need to know about it because whole JavaScript is based on this programming construct.

Let's try to understand it in a simple way ğŸ§µğŸ‘‡ğŸ»

ğŸ“Œ Responsive Web Design (RWD)

An extremely important topic in CSS. Responsive web design is little tricky but not so tough to master.

It covers

- media query
- layouts

ğŸ“Œ Layout

- CSS positioning
- Flexible box layout
- Grid layout

Structuring your website is essential as it provides better navigation and visualization of the content available on the site. Let's talk a little more about it and learn how we can create a proper layout

ğŸ“Œ Typography

Moving forward, typography is an essential thing of web page. A good font can make your webpage and establish a strong visual hierarchy, provide a graphic balance to the website, and set the product's overall tone

ğŸ“Œ The box-model

You will these every single time. Like website is based on the boxes and that's why this is very important 

The box-model covers 

- Height
- Width
- Padding
- Border
- Margin https://t.co/m3sr4B7BdE

The background in the shorthand property which cover background-color, background-attachment, etc

But again, you will rarely use background-attachment, background-origin, etc

First and foremost

ğŸ“Œ The background and color

The characterstic of a great website is it's color scheme. Forget about everything and learn about background and color properties initially
The colors are something from which users interact first whenever they visit your webpage

There are a lot of this types of properties is CSS which you never gonna use for sure.

Like, 
ğŸ“Œ caret-color
ğŸ“Œ mask-composite
ğŸ“Œ will-change

For example: Have you heard about "image-rendering property"?

If not, then its not a problem
if yes, then its great

This property basically defines the image scalinig algorithm https://t.co/PxaTBcx4II

You must have heard about "Pareto principle" which states that for many outcomes roughly 80% of consequences come from 20% of the causes

Similarly, in order to cover 80% of CSS, you need to learn only 20 properties https://t.co/fdXKEueheh

Obviously remembering them all and their values is almost impossible.

In my opinion, entire CSS revolves around 20 properties only
CSS is totally operates on properties value pair. And there are around ~300 distinct properties in CSS

CSS is an amazing and unique language that servers a great purpose. We can make our website visually good using CSS. It describe the presentation of web pages, including typography,. layouts, color etc...

CSS is also a deep module of web development. There are over 250 unique properties

Do we need to learn them all? Let's try to figure out how much CSS will be enough

Instead of using four diffrent transition property you can use only one CSS shorthand property called transition https://t.co/rJ1wG0W6wh

You can visualize all the curves here on the link

ğŸ”— https://t.co/eprezYrIae

You can pass following values in transition-timing-function property

- ease (slow start, then fast, then slow)
- linear (same speed)
- ease-in (slow start)
- ease-out (slow end)
- ease-in-out (slow start and slow end)
- cubic-bezier (customizable)

ğŸ“Œ transition-timing-function

The transition-timing-function property specifies the speed curve of the transition effect. Let's visualize it in next tweet

ğŸ“Œ transition-delay

As the property name suggests, it defines how long to wait between the time a property is changed and the transition actually begins. https://t.co/iRPda1oany

You can see height is changing is 2s and width in 4s as we have mentioned it respectively.

If in case there is only one value is transition-duration then it will applicable for all the properties mentioned in transition-property

Explanation:

Point A - height 100px
Point B - height 200px;

The div element changing its height from 100 to 200px in 2 seconds as mentioned in transition-duration property

ğŸ“Œ transition-duration

Transition duration is nothing but the time period in which transition occurs.

Let's try to play around with these two properties ğŸ‘‡ğŸ»

ğŸ“Œ transition-property

transition-property defines the name of CSS property/ies to which transition should be applied.

Learning CSS transition is not really difficult, you just need to learn four properties and that's it

transition-delay
transition-duration
transition-property
transition-timing-function

Transition is a like a two point operation. For example, suppose you're changing the height to an element when user hover it from 100px to 200px

In this case point A is 100px and point B is 200px

CSS transition and CSS animation are two closely related modules of CSS but they are different

For example, CSS animation runs automatically but the transition need to be triggered like hover

Introduction to CSS transitions â²ï¸

CSS transition add some smoothness in animation. By using it, you can change styling over a given duration instead of instantly

Hooks are broadly divided into two catrgories.

1. Basic hooks
   - useState
   - useEffect
   - useContext

2. Additional hooks
   - useReducer
   - useCallback
   - useMemo
   - useRef
   - useImperativeHandle
   - useLayoutEffect
   - useDebugValue
Be sure to add "use" keywords as prefix in the name of your custom hook. Without the use keyword, React wouldn't able to perform automatically error checking for you.

And that's it. I tried my best to give a quick overview of how CSS animations works

If you like this thread, drop a like and retweet, means a lot to me â¤ï¸ 

Peace out ğŸ˜‰
This is the correct order to animation shorthand property ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» https://t.co/SO5jKXz6iz

Let me explain animation-fill-mode by this video ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» 

- As you can see blue box stopped at left: 500px becuase forwards is begin applied on it
- And orange box has black background even it's in a delay period of 2 seconds because backwards is being applied on it https://t.co/HWPkY8GbQa

It accepts following value

- forwards (element will retain last keyframe styling)
- backwards (element will get the first keyframe value even in animation-delay period)
- both (both of the above)

One thing to note here is that animation do not affect element before or after the keyframes.

In order to persist the styling based on last or first keyframe, we have animation-fill-mode

See this video for better understanding or you can play with code here

https://t.co/AnNOPDBs5i https://t.co/B0NfEUXZNG
Here are some visual representation of speed curve ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» https://t.co/rWxS8af08O

You can pass following values in animation-timing function

- ease (slow start, then fast, then slow)
- linear (same speed)
- ease-in (slow start)
- ease-out (slow end)
- ease-in-out (slow start and slow end)
- cubic-bezier (customizable)
So far so good, But we can also change the speed curve of animation and can create more smooth animation. And we have animation-timing-function property for that.

We have another cool property called "animation-iteration-count"

It specifies the number of times an animation should run repeatedly. You can pass a numeral value or "infinite" in this property https://t.co/cMg7cWqs5E

Alright moving further, we can also pass percentage in keyframes rule and make some amazing animations

For example, suppose I want on change the background-color of an element https://t.co/Tx9Hfvuwls

Explanation:

Black box is going 500px from left boundary in 4 seconds because we have mentioned 4 seconds in animation property and 500px in keyframe at rule.
The output of above attached code: https://t.co/mx5q0DScVF

Lets create a simple animation which will solve all our doubts:

For example, suppose I want to move my element 500px left in four seconds. It's very easy https://t.co/l2yTZE8E4m

Either we can use each property of animation or we can use animation shorthand property which includes:

animation-name
animation-duration
animation-timing-function
animation-delay
animation-iteration-count
animation-direction
animation-fill-mode
animation-play-state

In order to bind the keyframe with a particular animation, we need to define few things like name and timing of animations.

We have several properties for that like animation-name, animation-timing, etc...
The syntax of keyframes at-rule ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» https://t.co/NGG8xJ3pZs

Animation is all about changing one style to another at certain intervals or times. For doing that, we need to learn about `@ keyframes` at rule

The keyframe provides us animation by changing the style sequentially according to the mentioned interval.
CSS animations is little tricky but not too tough to master. In this thread, we will try to gain some decent knowledge about it.

Before diving into it, we need to understand the importance of CSS animations

Animation can establish interaction between users and the user interface. This makes your website more interactive which ultimately attracts more visitors to your webpage.

A complete introduction to CSS animations ğŸš€

CSS animation is a module in CSS that lets you change the styling of elements and therefore creates an animate effect. It's little tricky but not much

So far we have discussed about 1 dimensional layout system. As you can see all element are very consistent and following same number of columns and row. Let's talk something about 2D

Responsiveness is one of the major thing we need to keep in my while forming a proper layout.

There are millions of devices on which your webpage will be viewed. We might run into some responsiveness issue if we use pixel unit.

As you can see there is a lot of repeated code in 
grid-template-columns: 200px 200px 200px 200px 200px;

Instead of this we can use repeat function

grid-template-columns: repeat(5, 200px); https://t.co/F7TDsfPyB4

gird-template-columns

CSS grid is the widely used layout methods nowadays. Let's talk about it in details ğŸ‘‡ğŸ»

Flex layout only deals with either column or row. It doesn't provide you the flexibility of positioning a element in inconsistent order.

Whereas Grid provides you the flexbility of adjusting element in both the directions either column or row.

We have a better way

Flex and grid CSS layout. The flexible box(flexbox) layout is one dimensional whereas the Grid layout is 2 dimensional

In CSS, you can create layouts using multi methods. For example positioning concept is also a method of achieving layout but its hard.

Its hard to handle the responsiveness of layout in different screen sizes if we use Position property

ğŸ“Œ How to make a layout

The oldest way of creating layouts is using HTML <table> tags. Tables are having column and rows so you can make use of it. But this method is out dated as now we have CSS which can handle layout

ğŸ“Œ Design vs Layout?

Web layout is closely related to designing part. But we can say that web designing is much more than the layout only. It covers images, text, color scheme, typography and layout

On the other hand, Layout is all about arrangement of element on the webpage

Web layout aims for presenting imformation in a logical manner and to make the important elements stand out.

A well designed layout can catch more traffic on your website and make your content easy to understand

STEP 6: Create second Eye

- Create second eye using same technique and code
- Just position it differently https://t.co/ceMzPLmtzK

STEP 5: Create an eye

- For eye we need an oval shape (height > width)
- Apply black border with white background color
- Position it behind the nose https://t.co/ztTxEoFgUl

We need to extend the border of nose so that it looks like the nose is coming out of the face. 

Again, we can do that using pseudo-elements

- Just create a small rectangle with same border and adjust it to the top border of nose https://t.co/JlaWj7gtUl

STEP 4: Create a Nose

- Make a square
- Apply solid border of same color as of face
- border-right: none - in order to match it with the face boundary
- Position and rotate it so that it sync with the face https://t.co/cs0RKSAg9l

STEP 3: Create a Ear

- Create a circle
- Give it a solid right and bottom border of color same as face
- Rotate it a bit in order to match the boundary of ear to face https://t.co/Rq6HLkltVA

STEP 2: Create Lips

- Make a small square
- Add bottom and left border
- Skew it so that it seems like a lip
- Add little bit of bottom-left radius to give it a more realistic look https://t.co/UICwwWfCWH

STEP 1: Create a Face of rectangular shape

- Create a rectangle and rotate it a little bit
- Give it a solid border without border-bottom
- Position it https://t.co/s2xr3NsaR5

ğŸ“Œ Events

 You can handle various events using JavaScript. An event can be defined as something the browser does, or something a user does.

For example, click is a event that user does, whereas onload is a event when user enters the page

Using HTML DOM you can 

- Catch element in JavaScript file
- Change whatever you want
- Add or delete element

JavaScript - HTML DOM methods

You might know that JavaScript is for adding behaviour in your webpage. For that you need to catch the HTML element so that you can change things accordingly

HTML DOM methods are actions
HTML DOM properties are values that you can set

JavaScript is used to add some functionality in website. So that user can interact with the website. For that we have two basic methods:

The another interesting part about is JavaScript is that you can start with it right away. Let me tell you how!?

You can run JavaScript on the client side and on the server side as well. Which means you can run JavaScript code right in your browser.

Whenever setTimeout comes in stack, it is sent to web API which waits for the specified time to send this operation back to event queue.

Hence it is a cycle like this ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» https://t.co/xmWYD9waQk

Event queue is a queue data structure which sends all the operation into call stack in order.

One key point to note here is that if an async function is called, it is sent to web API. For example setTimeout method.

ğŸ“Œ Event loop

Call stack - It keeps all the operations in order which has to be executed. After successful execution, it is popped out.

Event Queue -  It is responsible for sending new functions to the track for processing. https://t.co/sZsynpvy6N

Although JavaScript is a single threaded language but we have a concept called event loop.

Using a few smart data structures we can achieve the multi threaded functionality in JavaScript. Let's talk more about it ğŸ‘‡ğŸ»

ğŸ“Œ JavaScript is a single threaded language

In simple terms we can say that JavaScript executes code in order and must finish executing a piece code before moving onto the next one.

Does this make JavaScript a slow language? No ğŸ‘‡ğŸ»

And that's it. You just created your first react app. I tried my best to give a quick overview of how things work in React

If you like this thread, drop a like and retweet, means a lot to me â¤ï¸

Peace out ğŸ˜‰

Once done, run "npm start"

Your default browser will launch automatically and you will see something like this at localhost:3000 https://t.co/QYUodlUlcr

Now you have create-react-app installed in your machine, it's time to create your first React app

Command - "create-react-app app-name"

Depending upon your internet speed, this will take some minutes. So time to prepare a coffee for yourself â˜•
Next thing you need to install is `create-react-app` is a tool helps you start building with React app. It set up all the tools that you need in order to get started

Setting up your first react project directory is quite confusing. Let's see how you can do it

I'm assuming you have node environment set up and up-to-date version of npm. If no, download it from here

 https://t.co/5Om0LeuKxr

Whenever the new element is added to the UI, a new virtual DOM associated with that element is created. If state of this element changes, a second new virtual DOM is created which will be compared with the previous virtual DOM

- It then updates ONLY the object on the real DOM https://t.co/f9AHPI4P3F

Every time the DOM changes, browser need to recalculate entire layout and then repaint the web page which makes a web app slow. 

To overcome this we have virtual DOM
Every time the state of our application changes, the virtual DOM gets updated instead of the real DOM

A very important concept in React

Virtual DOM

You might have heard the term "DOM", virtual DOM is kind of similar. It uses a strategy that updates the DOM without having to redraw all the webpage elements

Now we know JSX, let's move forward

- Functional components are nothing but simply a JavaScript function which takes some parameter will return some JSX code

A typical function component ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» https://t.co/DMk8GsTUFO

const element = <h1>Hello, world!</h1>;

Consider this variable declaration. It's neither JS nor HTML. This is the mixture of JavaScript + XML = JSX

Before diving deeper into it, let's talk a little bit about JSX

- JSX stands for JavaScript XML. It's basically nothing but the extension of JavaScript which allow us to write HTML code in JavaScript file.

Components are of two types:

1ï¸âƒ£ Class based components 
2ï¸âƒ£ functional based components 

Class-based components are defined using ES6 classes, whereas function components are basic JavaScript functions

Attached image showing a typical React app with all different components. 
As you can see this entire webpage is nothing but the mixture of different components https://t.co/SIMKuvlNtT

A typical React app contain many components. They are reusable and can interact with each other.

What is a component?
- Component as a simple function that you can call with some input and they render some output

Why React?

1. Reusable components
2. Fast due to virtual DOM
3. Huge ecosystem

Introduction to React âš›ï¸

React is a JavaScript library for building UI components. The ecosystem of React is really immense which eventually makes it one of the best front-end libraries

So far we have discussed the basics of useEffect. 

Let's build something useful using it. We will be using useEffect for fetching some COVID data

{ 11 / 15 } https://t.co/rw3dBx1siM

In useEffect we can also perform clean up

If we return a function within the method, this function perform basically a clean up of what we did last time.

{ 9 / 15 } https://t.co/vQnegBRVjw

ğŸš¨ Here's an important thing to note is that if you pass an empty array then it will only run on once. 
No matter how many times you render your component, the useEffect will run only once because the value of empty array never going to change

{ 8 / 15 } https://t.co/EmSQMyu2kG

As you can see when I click on the re-render button, our useEffect run this is because I have passed render state inside dependency array

{ 7 / 15 } https://t.co/8pZSxZPJik

But let's say if I add some dependency in the array and pass the array as second parameter then useEffect will only run when the value of dependency array change. 

For example, let me modify the code little bit so that you can understand it better

{ 6 / 15 } https://t.co/xqstvxaze1

As you can see in the output the function is executed every single time my component re-render

{ 5 / 15 } https://t.co/yula9nnBnt

useEffect take two parameters, first is a function and second is an array.

The function inside the useEffect will run every single time component re-render. Consider this piece of code and check the output in next tweet

{ 4 / 15 } https://t.co/Q86zEyLIzA

By using useEffect, you tell React that your component needs to do something after render. React will remember the function you passed (we'll refer to it as our â€œeffectâ€), and call it later after performing the DOM updates

So let's start by understanding the syntax first

3/15 https://t.co/Dtyj9YxzDr

useEffect hook is the heart of React functional components

If you're familiar with class components then you might know that we have various lifecycle methods but in functional components, we don't have any lifecycle methods. Instead we have a powerful hook called useEffect

React Hooks are the functions which "hook into" React state and lifecycle features from function components. Hooks allows you to manipulate state and other React feature without writing a class. Let's talk about widely used hook
